did.abstract: The daybook of 1805-1823 contains, among other things, an account with Robert Fulton for painting supplies; an account with Thomas Jefferson Randolph for admission to lectures on chemistry, purchase of instruments, etc., with notes of payment by Thomas Jefferson; and accounts with Peale's children.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition note
acqinfo.p: Purchased from Charles Coleman Sellers and accessioned, 1945 (85235, 85236).

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies note
altformavail.p: This collection is also available in microfilm (Film 240). The papers of C. W. Peale and his family have been reproduced almost in their entirety in microfiche form (Lillian B. Miller, ed. "Collected papers of Charles Willson Peale and his family." Kraus Microfilm, 1980).

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Charles Willson Peale was an artist and naturalist.

odd.head: Early American History Not
odd.p: Charles Willson Peale’s daybooks consist of two large volumes that contain his daily activities for the years 1805-1824.

The first daybook primarily records financial data and transactions. There is a name index in the back that may not be accurate, but does contain the names of many prominent Americans with whom Peale conducted business.

The second daybook contains far more information, often relating daily activities in a diary-like manner. Peale records details on the weather, gardening, painting, and social life in this second volume. Most of these events took place on Peale’s 100+ acre farm outside of Germantown.

odd.head: Administrative Note
odd.p: This record is superseded by, and included in, B P31. It was marked “internal only” in Dec., 2010 and is being kept in the case that it is needed for future administrative needs.
